messageBody:
Curt Sampson wrote:

>
> public void myPublicMethod()
> {
> // no problem mocking the HTTP Servlet Reqest
> params = readParamsFromHttpServletRequest();
> myPrivateMethod(params);
>
> // How do I mock either 'client' or 'ServiceLocator'
> OrgMgrServiceClient client = getOrgMgrServiceClient();
> client.doStuff();
> }
>
> private OrgMgrServiceClient _client;
>
> private OrgMgrServiceClient getOrgMgrServiceClient() {
> if (_client != null)
> return _client;
> else
> return ServiceLocator.getOrgMgrServiceClient();
> }
>
> void setOrgMgrServiceClient(OrgMgrServiceClient client) {
> _client = client;
> }

That's a standard pattern: setter injection. /Now/ you can mock easily.
I had thought that you weren't allowed to change that class at all --
but if you were able to add methods to it, that changes everything.

Good job.
